Definition: A mix of processes and products used in the application of knowledge. It includes tools ranging from pencil and paper to electronic gadgets.
A diverse set of technological tools and resources used to transmit, store, create, or exchange information.
A broad set of modalities, tools, and strategies for learning that helps teachers and students achieve the desired instructional goals.

The ability to use information and communication technologies to find, evaluate, create, and communicate information, requiring both cognitive and technical skills including finding and consuming digital content, creating digital content, and communicating or sharing it.

Any type of learning that is accompanied by technology or by instructional practice that makes effective use of technology encompassing a wide spectrum of practices, including blended learning or virtual learning, and can be online or offline, utilizing digital technology.

Modality with instructional environments supported by the Internet within and beyond school walls to provide access to instructional materials and facilitate interaction among teachers and students. It can be fully online or blended with face-to-face interactions.
Modality where students receive significant portions of instruction through both face-to-face and online means.

Learning that occurs when learners and instructors interact in real-time, typically through delivery platforms, distance learning technologies such as video conferencing, discussion forums and community chat, or collaboration and social learning technologies.
Instructional design and delivery methodology that allows students to access content or participate in learning outside of the classroom at their convenience.
A temporary shift of instructional delivery to an alternative mode due to crisis circumstances.
Web-based tools that require an internet connection to function, such as Google Docs, Kahoot, and Zoom.
Software or applications that can be used without an internet connection, like Microsoft Word, Adobe Photoshop, or offline coding platforms.
The use of technology, such as digital tools and multimedia, to enhance teaching and learning processes.
A set of instructions or programs that allow computers or devices to perform specific tasks, such as Microsoft Office or educational apps.
The combination of different content forms, such as text, images, audio, video, and animations, to present information interactively.
A global network of interconnected computers that enables communication, data sharing, and online access to digital resources.
A system of interconnected web pages and online content accessible via the internet through browsers.
Software programs designed for specific functions, available on mobile devices or computers. Examples include Duolingo for language learning or Evernote for note-taking.
Electronic tools, systems, and devices that generate, store, or process data, including computers, smartphones, and cloud-based applications.
A collection of slides used for presentations, often created with tools like PowerPoint or Google Slides.
Software for creating, editing, and formatting text documents (e.g., Microsoft Word, Google Docs).
A digital tool for organizing, analyzing, and visualizing data in tabular form (e.g., Excel, Google Sheets).
Technology-driven personalized learning that adjusts to students' progress.
Using game-like elements in education to increase engagement.
Responsible use of technology and online interactions.
Tools that support learners with disabilities, such as screen readers or speech-to-text.
An AI model trained on vast amounts of text data to understand and generate human-like language.
Technology that enables machines to simulate human intelligence, including learning, reasoning, and problem-solving.
An online course aimed at unlimited participation and open access via the internet.
The unequal access to digital technology, including smartphones, tablets, laptops, and the internet.
Framework that guides educators, leaders and coaches in using technology to create high-impact, sustainable, scalable and equitable learning experiences.
A regularly updated website or online journal where individuals or organizations share written content, insights, and multimedia.
A collaborative website that allows multiple users to create, edit, and share information, such as Wikipedia or educational wikis.
A digital audio series that covers various topics and can be streamed or downloaded for on-the-go listening.
A blog that primarily features video content, often posted on platforms like YouTube.
Technology that enables live video and audio communication between individuals or groups over the internet, such as Zoom or Microsoft Teams.
Platforms that facilitate online conversations and debates, such as discussion forums, chat applications, and social media.
Online message boards where users post and reply to topics, often used for academic or professional discussions.
Online spaces where users can engage in real-time conversations, often used for support, brainstorming, or peer interaction.
Digital tools that allow users to work together in real time, such as Google Docs, Slack, or Microsoft Teams.
Digital platforms that support social interactions, networking, and content sharing, including Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn.
A teaching model where students learn new content at home (via videos or readings) and use classroom time for discussions and activities.
Tools and platforms that support remote education, such as learning management systems (LMS) and virtual classrooms.
A software platform used to manage, deliver, and track educational courses and training programs, such as Moodle, Blackboard, or Canvas.
